instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
Hello, 
I have this board, water damaged, no power 

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>    3,4    
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>    12.59    
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>    3,3    
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>             5 
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>          3,3    
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>    3,36    

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> does have a ~3.2V pulse when first hooking power up. the pulse lasts about 20 milliseconds,

I soldered a wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and I touched to the ground
 <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>  don't react at the same time.
<SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL> is high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
If you cannot catch a drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>, should be a SMC issue.
As always for water damaged boards, I recommend to start reballing SMC.
Do you get steady high <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
yes i have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drop when <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> shorted
SMC replaced no change

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
Check traces and components around SMC.
Also inspect entire board for corrosion.
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
The board trying to start but it stop, 
normally it consume 0.01A but suddenly it jump to 0.20-0.30A and to come back to 0.2
I can't find  broken traces it is clean

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> don't react at the same time."
That is impossible, if the board tries to start.
You've also said
"<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> does have a ~3.2V pulse when first hooking power up"
Does it happen only when connect charger?
No reaction of any <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals when trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
sorry, I was wrong.
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> react when I short <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> get high every ~10 sec for 20ms, but no reaction when I trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
Check for pulse at all big coils.
At same time of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message: yes, there are pulses on the big coils at the same time <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> pulse.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
Then you have pulses at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>0_L</SIGNAL> too.
VCORE tries to appear?
Also check if all voltages from page 63 pulse; one power rail may be shorted to ground.

"Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?"
???

Any pulse at pins 7 & 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?
You can also try a known good BIOS file.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
002 in diode mode means 4-5 ohms and could be good value for VCORE.

"check if all voltages from page 63 pulse; one power rail may be shorted to ground."
???

Pay atention to 5V filter caps for audio...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 0.3ohms
on page 63 all signals are pulsing and nothing shorted to froung

"Pay atention to 5V filter caps for audio..." where is this cap, sorry i am still learning

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no S4 state
threads.message: Look at schematic, audio area and there should be some 4.5-5v rails; <CAPACITOR>C6412</CAPACITOR>/22/32/42...
